OUTPUT: ['Novel - A long fictional narrative book, typically longer than a short story but shorter than a novel.', 'Epilogue - The concluding section or passage at the end of a book which summarizes what happens to its characters after the main events have concluded.', 'Prologue - An introductory section of an epic poem or extended work, often providing background information on the plot and setting.', 'Chapter - A division within books that separates content into sections for easier reading.', 'Page - One side of a sheet of paper in a book, typically containing a single vertical column of text.', 'Paragraph - A self-contained unit of discourse comprising one or more sentences having a common central theme or idea.', 'Plot - The sequence of events that make up a storyline within the structure of a novel, play, film, or other narrative forms.', 'Subplot - A secondary strand of the plot in a play, movie, or novel, which is not as important as the main plot but still contributes to it.', 'Preamble - An introductory statement that precedes and explains the purpose and intentions of a document or piece of literature.', 'Index - A list at the end of a book providing references to where specific information can be found within the text.', 'Table of Contents - A list, usually placed at the beginning of a book, indicating the titles and starting page numbers of its chapters or sections.', 'Blurb - A short promotional description on the back cover of a book that highlights key aspects or themes.', 'Author - The person who writes a book, typically recognized for their works in literature.', 'Publisher - A company that produces and disseminates books to the public through various distribution channels.', 'ISBN (International Standard Book Number) - An 10- or 13-digit number assigned to individual books, which facilitates identification and ordering by retailers.', "Spine - The side of a bound book that displays the title and author's name, visible when shelved in a library.", 'Margins - The spaces between the text and the edges of a page or around headings and images within a book.', 'Cover Art - The illustration or design on the front cover of a book that often serves as an enticement for potential readers.', 'Footnotes/Endnotes - Supplementary notes placed at the bottom (footnotes) or end (endnotes) of a page in a text, providing additional information, citations, or clarification to the main content.', 'Protagonist - The leading character or one of the major characters in a story, often regarded as good or heroic.']

['Danzón - A traditional Cuban music and dance genre popular in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.', 'Cha-Cha - A lively, rhythmic dance originating from Cuba which gained international fame with its influence on Latin American dance styles.', 'Rumba - The most famous Cuban dance style known for its sensual movements, often performed to Afro-Cuban percussion and melodies.', 'Mambo - A musical genre that evolved from the mambo rhythm in Cuba during the 1940s and became a popular dance form worldwide.', 'Guaracha - A fast-paced Cuban music style with playful lyrics, often associated with comedic performances on stage or at social gatherings.', 'Salsa - Although more commonly associated with Puerto Rican culture, salsa also has roots in Cuban dance and originated from the combination of various Latin American dances.', 'Pachanga - A fast-paced, energetic Cuban dance style that became popular during the 1950s alongside the mambo craze.', 'Son Montuno - A musical form based on the son clave rhythm and a significant element of traditional Cuban music and dance.', 'Guajira - A folkloric dance from Cuba often performed in rural areas, characterized by its slow, graceful movements and Afro-Cuban melodies.', 'Danzon Criollo - A form of Cuban danzón which is considered to be the precursor to danzón nuevo style.', 'Danzón Nuevo - A modernized version of traditional Cuban danzón, featuring faster tempos and more dynamic choreography.', 'Conga - Originally a folkloric Cuban dance, conga later spread to other Latin American countries and became popular in the United States as well.', 'Bolero - A slow, romantic Cuban music and dance style that dates back to the early 20th century', 'Chachachá - A lively, fast-paced Cuban dance characterized by a distinctive rhythm created by an instrument called a chacha-chá.', 'Chaoco - An informal Cuban dance that involves quick footwork and energetic movements often performed at social events or gatherings.', 'Calipso - Although more closely associated with the Caribbean, this Afro-Cuban folkloric dance form has strong Cuban influences and is characterized by its lively music and intricate choreography.', 'Abakuá - A secret society originating from West Africa but heavily influenced by Cuban culture, abakuá dance involves complex movements performed in a circle with participants wearing special attire.', 'Batucada - A musical genre featuring percussion instruments like congas and timbales, often accompanied by Afro-Cuban dances such as samba or carimbó.', 'Salsa Cubana - Also known as cubop, this fusion dance style emerged in the 1970s combining elements of Latin American rhythms like salsa and mambo with jazz improvisation.', 'Caliptrao - ['Disadvantaged - experiencing an unfavorable situation or condition due to lack of resources, opportunities, etc.', 'Underprivileged - having less material wealth or fewer social privileges than others.', 'Marginalized - pushed to the edge or fringe of society and given limited power, influence, or access.', 'Ostracized - excluded from a group due to differences or perceived wrongdoings.', 'Ignored - overlooked or disregarded intentionally by others.', 'Underrepresented - not adequately represented or reflected in a particular area or population.', 'Disenfranchised - deprived of the right to vote and participate in political processes.', 'Marginalized - pushed to the fringes of society due to race, gender, sexual orientation, etc.', "Persecuted - subjected to harassment or oppression because of one's beliefs, religion, or identity.", 'Disenfranchised - deprived of rights and privileges that are typically granted to others in the same position.', 'Left out - excluded from social activities or events.', 'Subjugated - subjected to domination or control by another person, group, or authority.', 'Marginalized - pushed to the margins of society due to poverty, disability, etc.', 'Overlooked - not noticed or considered despite qualifications and contributions.', 'Discriminated against - unfairly treated based on race, gender, sexual orientation, religion, etc.', 'Excluded - denied access or participation in something due to various reasons.', 'At-risk - facing a higher likelihood of negative outcomes due to certain circumstances (e.g., poverty, family instability).', 'Marginalized communities - populations that face social and economic disadvantages due to systemic barriers.', 'Victims of circumstance - individuals who are impacted by unfavorable conditions or situations they have no control over.', "Disparaged - criticized, belittled, or disparaged due to one's characteristics or background."]

['Past - refers to events or situations occurring before the present time.', 'Yesteryear - another word for the past, often referring to days gone by.', 'Antiquity - a term used to describe ancient times or things from long ago.', 'Historical - relating to history and events that have happened previously.', 'Precedent - an event in the past that serves as an example or guide for future actions.', 'Bygone - referring to something or someone from a previous time period, often nostalgic.', 'Antebellum - typically used in reference to the time before a war, especially the American Civil War.', 'Retrospective - looking back at events that have occurred previously.', 'Pre-existing - referring to something or someone that existed or was known prior to a specific event.', 'Vintage - relating to products or styles from an earlier time period, often with nostalgic connotations.', 'Previous - directly preceding another event or item; prior to current situation.', 'Earlier - occurring at a time before the present moment, more specifically before a particular point of reference.', 'Former - used for someone who held an office or position previously but is no longer in that role.', 'Predecessor - a person or thing that came before another; former holder of a job or title.', 'Prior - existing, happening, or coming before something else in time, order, or importance.', 'Beforehand - occurring at an earlier time prior to the main event or action taking place.', 'Previously mentioned - referring to information previously discussed in a text or conversation.', 'Long past - indicating that the time period referred to is significantly further back than just before now.', 'Once upon a time - a common phrase used when starting a story set in an earlier era, often with historical elements.']

['Arrow - Traditional projectile weapon used by various cultures, sometimes associated with hunting animals for their hides or furs.', 'Bow and arrow - A combination tool used historically to launch arrows at targets; not directly involved in obtaining animal skins but related to the method of hunting.', 'Catapult - An ancient siege engine that launched projectiles, including stones or other objects, toward fortifications rather than animals for their skins specifically.', 'Cannons - Gunpowder-propelled weapons used in warfare; not designed for acquiring animal hides.', 'Atlatl (or Spear-thrower) - A tool that uses leverage to throw a spear farther and with more force than by hand alone, traditionally hunting game rather than skins specifically.', "Grapnel - Although primarily used for net fishing or securing anchors, its use could potentially include capturing animals indirectly; however, it's not directly associated with acquiring animal hides.", 'Harpoon - A long spear-like instrument traditionally used to catch large fish and marine mammals like whales (historically valuable for their blubber), but can be loosely connected due to hunting activities.', "Crossbow - While crossbows are primarily known as a weapon, they have been historically used in hunting animals; however, it's not specific to missiles or skins acquisition.", 'Ballista - A large ancient siege engine designed for throwing projectiles at fortifications and enemy combatants rather than specifically targeting animal hides.', 'Quill pen - Although unrelated directly to missile launchers, quills were historically used in writing documentation related to hunting or trade of skins.', 'The listed items are closely associated with weaponry and tools from historical contexts where acquiring animals could indirectly involve their hides.']
